original_text: It is critical to the success of the NPD technique that the MOF complex adsorbs a significant amount of D2 to boost the observed signal. This technique therefore has disadvantages when studying the binding interaction within MOFs with low uptakes. Furthermore, static crystallographic studies cannot provide insights into the dynamics of the adsorbed gas molecules. Thus, it is very challenging to probe experimentally the H2 binding interactions within a porous host system which has very low gas uptake due to the lack of suitable characterisation techniques. We report herein the application of the in situ inelastic neutron scattering (INS) technique to permit direct observation of the dynamics of the binding interactions between adsorbed H2 molecules and an aluminium-based porous MOF, NOTT-300, exhibiting moderate porosity, narrow pore window and very low uptake of H2. This neutron spectroscopy study reveals that adsorbed H2 molecules do not interact with the organic ligand within the pore channels, and form very weak interactions with [Al(OH)2O4] moieties via a type of through-spacing interaction (Al-O⋯H2). Interestingly, the very low H2 adsorption has been successfully characterised as weak binding interactions and, for the first time, we have found that the adsorbed H2 in the pore channel has a liquid type recoil motion at 5K (below its melting point) as a direct result of this weak interaction to the MOF host.
original_translation: Es fundamental para el éxito de la técnica de NPD que el complejo MOF adsorba una cantidad significativa de D2 para aumentar la señal observada. Esta técnica, por lo tanto, tiene desventajas al estudiar la interacción de unión dentro de los MOFs con baja captación. Además, los estudios cristalográficos estáticos no pueden proporcionar información sobre la dinámica de las moléculas de gas adsorbidas. Por lo tanto, es muy desafiante investigar experimentalmente las interacciones de unión de H2 dentro de un sistema de anfitrión poroso que tiene una muy baja absorción de gas debido a la falta de técnicas de caracterización adecuadas. Informamos aquí sobre la aplicación de la técnica de dispersión inelástica de neutrones in situ (INS) para permitir la observación directa de la dinámica de las interacciones de unión entre las moléculas de H2 adsorbidas y un MOF poroso a base de aluminio, NOTT-300, que presenta una porosidad moderada, una ventana de poro estrecha y una muy baja captación de H2. Este estudio de espectroscopía de neutrones revela que las moléculas de H2 adsorbidas no interactúan con el ligando orgánico dentro de los canales porosos, y forman interacciones muy débiles con los grupos [Al(OH)2O4] a través de un tipo de interacción de espaciado (Al-O⋯H2). Curiosamente, la muy baja adsorción de H2 ha sido caracterizada con éxito como interacciones de unión débil y, por primera vez, hemos descubierto que el H2 adsorbido en el canal del poro tiene un movimiento de retroceso tipo líquido a 5K (por debajo de su punto de fusión) como resultado directo de esta débil interacción con el anfitrión MOF.

Por lo tanto, es muy desafiante investigar experimentalmente las interacciones de unión de H2 dentro de un sistema de anfitrión poroso que tiene una muy baja absorción de gas debido a la falta de técnicas de caracterización adecuadas. Informamos aquí sobre la aplicación de la técnica de dispersión inelástica de neutrones in situ (INS) para permitir la observación directa de la dinámica de las interacciones de unión entre las moléculas de H2 adsorbidas y un MOF poroso a base de aluminio, NOTT-300, que presenta una porosidad moderada, una ventana de poro estrecha y una muy baja captación de H2. Este estudio de espectroscopía de neutrones revela que las moléculas de H2 adsorbidas no interactúan con el ligando orgánico dentro de los canales porosos, y forman interacciones muy débiles con los grupos [Al(OH)2O4] a través de un tipo de interacción de espaciado (Al-O⋯H2). We report herein the application of the in situ inelastic neutron scattering (INS) technique to permit direct observation of the dynamics of the binding interactions between adsorbed H2 molecules and an aluminium-based porous MOF, NOTT-300, exhibiting moderate porosity, narrow pore window and very low uptake of H2.

This neutron spectroscopy study reveals that adsorbed H2 molecules do not interact with the organic ligand within the pore channels, and form very weak interactions with [Al(OH)2O4] moieties via a type of through-spacing interaction (Al-O⋯H2).

Interestingly, the very low H2 adsorption has been successfully characterised as weak binding interactions and, for the first time, we have found that the adsorbed H2 in the pore channel has a liquid type recoil motion at 5K (below its melting point) as a direct result of this weak interaction to the MOF host.

We report herein the application of the
in situ inelastic neutron scattering
(INS) technique to permit direct observation of the dynamics of the binding interactions between adsorbed H2 molecules and an aluminium-based porous MOF, NOTT-300, exhibiting moderate porosity, narrow pore window and very low uptake of H2.

This neutron spectroscopy study reveals that adsorbed H2 molecules do not interact with the organic ligand within the pore channels, and form very weak interactions with [Al(OH)2O4] moieties via a type of through-spacing interaction (Al-O⋯H2).

Interestingly, the very low H2 adsorption has been successfully characterised as weak binding interactions and, for the first time, we have found that the adsorbed H2 in the pore channel has a liquid type recoil motion at 5K (below its melting point) as a direct result of this weak interaction to the MOF host.

original_annotated_sentences: It is critical to the success of the NPD technique that the MOF complex adsorbs a significant amount of D2 to boost the observed signal.
This technique therefore has disadvantages when studying the binding interaction within MOFs with low uptakes.

We report herein the application of the in situ inelastic neutron scattering (INS) technique to permit direct observation of the dynamics of the binding interactions between adsorbed H2 molecules and an aluminium-based porous MOF, NOTT-300, exhibiting moderate porosity, narrow pore window and very low uptake of H2.

This neutron spectroscopy study reveals that adsorbed H2 molecules do not interact with the
organic ligand
within the pore channels, and form very weak interactions with [Al(OH)2O4] moieties via a type of through-spacing interaction (Al-O⋯H2).

Interestingly, the very low H2 adsorption has been successfully characterised as weak binding interactions and, for the first time, we have found that the adsorbed H2 in the pore channel has a liquid type recoil motion at 5K (below its melting point) as a direct result of this weak interaction to the MOF host.
